header: Tom's home insurance policy includes coverage for storm damage and maintenance damage, defined as "damage caused by a storm." A storm is defined with: Hail of such intensity that it causes damage to hard surfaces or breaks glass, Torrential rainfall at a rate of at least 25mm per hour, Snow to a depth of at least 12 inches (30cms) in 24 hours, Wind speeds with gusts of at least 48 knots (55 mph).
continuation: Tom's home is in optimal condition. It's relatively new and he recently had a home inspection to confirm the conditions mentioned in his policy are met. One day, rainfall and wind gusts up to 40 mph cause damage to Tom's home. There is no hail, but several windows and hard surfaces are damaged, likely from projectiles picked up by the wind. Not wanting to pay out of pocket, Tom remembers his insurance policy. When he calls his insurer, however, the insurer disputes his claim, claiming that the damage Tom experienced is uncovered.

header: Miranda's homeowner's insurance policy includes coverage for "escape of water" damage, defined as "damage to buildings and contents caused by a sudden, unforeseen flow of water from an internal source, such as a burst pipe, boiler or faulty appliance."
continuation: Miranda has a modest home in the mountains. One day, a wildfire breaks out and Miranda's automatic sprinkler system engages to protect her home. When the fire subsides, Miranda discovers that several of her driveway is flooded due to her sprinkler system. When she calls her insurer, however, the insurer disputes Miranda's claim, claiming that the damage Miranda experienced does not constitute an escape of water.
